text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgaria's President Petar Stoyanov discussed the possible integration of Bulgaria in NATO with the visiting U.S. Defence Secretary William Cohen.

-- Bulgaria expects to start building a Hilton hotel in Sofia in September, Deputy Prime Minister Evgeni Bakardzhiev said. The World Bank's International Finance Corporation may extend $46.7 million to fund the project.

-- Bulgaria's Agriculture Ministry said it planned joint initiatives with the Interior Ministry to halt possible grains exports by strong arm criminal groups, Agriculture Minister Ventsislav Varbanov said.
-- Bulgaria's state Neftochim refinery said it would organise tenders for crude oil suppliers. At present the refinery is choosing its suppliers through direct negotiations.
-- Bulgaria's Finance Ministry said it had set up a new group of experts to manage country's foreign debt. The experts will propose debt management programmes to the cabinet.
The group is headed by Deputy Finance Minister Plamen Oresharski and the government's representative is George Prohaski, who is economic adviser to Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Bozhkov.

-- Bulgaria expects to seal in 10 days an investment adviser contract with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell for the privatisation of Bulgarian Telecommunication Company, Bulgaria's Posts and Communications Committee executive director Antoni Slavinski said.

-- Bulgaria's Interior Ministry said it had sanctioned 3,634 police officers who were involved in 440 incidents in the first six months of this year in a move to tighten discipline among police officers.
-- Bulgaria's Finance Ministry said it would restructure tax services in a move to boost budget revenue after August 1. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 91188
